sen.j: 和尚魚（おしょううお）は、江戸時代の百科辞典『和漢三才図会』にある海の妖怪で、海坊主の一種。
sen.e: Oshouo' refers to a kind of 'Umibozu', a 'yokai' (apparitions, spirits, spooks or monsters) living in the ocean recorded in an encyclopedia, "Wakansansaizue", compiled in the Edo period.

sen.j: 体はスッポンに似ており、頭部は「和尚」の名の通り頭髪がない坊主頭のように見える。
sen.e: Their body resembles 'suppon' (Chinese soft-shelled turtle) and their head looks bald as its name suggests 'monk'.

sen.j: これを捕らえて殺そうとすると、和尚魚は手を合わせて涙を流しつつ命乞いをした。
sen.e: When people tried to capture 'oshouo' kill it, it desperately begged for its life with tears.

sen.j: そのため、「助けてやるが、その代わり二度と祟ってはいけない」と言い聞かせて海へ逃がすと良いという。
sen.e: Therefore, it is said that it is good for people to release it to the sea, persuading not to curse them because they release it.

sen.j: また、同様にカメの体に坊主頭の人間の頭部を持つ海坊主として入亀入道（いりかめにゅうどう）があり、若狭湾に出現するといわれる。
sen.e: Also, it is said that another 'Umibozu' called 'Irikame nyudo' which has a turtle-like body and a human-like bald head appears in Wakasa Bay.

sen.e: It is considered as the same as 'oshouo' in an essay, "Tankai" written by Soan TSUMURA in the Edo period.

sen.e: Therefore, it is said that when people happened to catch it, they gave it sake (Japanese alcoholic beverage) and released it to the sea.

sen.j: 妖怪探訪家・村上健司はこの和尚魚や入亀入道を、ウミガメを妖怪視したものと推測している。
sen.e: Kenji MURAKAMI who researches and studies 'yokai' presumes that people figured sea turtles as 'yokai' such as 'oshouo' and 'Irikame nyudo'.
